The nonverbal and unquantifiable information is often called quality; the verbal and quantifiable information is often called quantity. Science requires the understanding of both qualitative and quantitative understanding. Many a scientist tend to think that being scientific means little qualitative information and almost only quantitative information. Surely, this brings a false sense of superiority, but it hinders first and foremost the understanding of nature of the scientist, and then the masses. The reason why quantum mechanics and general relativity are so difficult to understand, is the heavy reliance on matrices, i.e. tensors. Equations are there to bring us qualitative understandings, not to intimidate the masses, especially girls, from studying it. After all, most scientists obsessed with linear algebra remember those equations by heart, just like little girls doing good at arts subjects in high school.

Meet Dr Peter van der Kamp, Senior Lecturer in Mathematics. ‚ÄúIn my research I am an explorer, turning stones to find beauty, or what could be a new species in the mathematical universe. When I teach, I want to express beauty through mathematics,‚Äù Dr van der Kamp says. In addition to being an academic, Dr van der Kamp is also an artist who creates images from mathematical equations. ‚ÄúMy art is important because it speaks louder than formulas. Each piece carries layers of meaning, each colour and curve is determined by numbers, and each piece tells a story,‚Äù he says. The artwork Dr van der Kamp is holding is titled 'Consideration'. A 200-year-old theory of Lagrange multipliers has been used to find three concentric circles that touch the parabola, a u-shaped symmetrical curve. ‚ÄúThis piece is dedicated to my father," he explains. "It holds specific meanings for me. His approach to life, and art, is quite considerate. Most considerations are internal, but their manifestation will be presented beautifully. Life itself is optimisation and freedom is when you can create your own objective function and constraints." Happy National Mathematics Day! This day is celebrated on the birth anniversary of legendary mathematician Srinivasa Ramanujan. Ramanujan, a self-taught genius, used to amaze colleagues with his intuition. Legend has it that he found connections between numbers and the mathematical cosmos that others couldn‚Äôt even fathom. He once said his formulas came to him in dreams‚Äîtalk about a mathematical dreamland! Despite facing challenges, Ramanujan produced over 3900 results in his short life, uncovering new realms of number theory. His notebooks are like treasure maps to mathematical wonders! Let‚Äôs toast to Ramanujan, the maestro of math, and sprinkle a bit of his dreamy magic in our own calculations today! #NationalMathematicsDay #RamanujanMagic

What the mathematician #TerenceTao says about #Rigor_and_Intuition? The point of rigour is not to destroy all intuition; instead, it should be used to destroy bad intuition while clarifying and elevating good intuition. It is only with a combination of both rigorous formalism and good intuition that one can tackle complex mathematical problems; one needs the former to correctly deal with the fine details, and the latter to correctly deal with the big picture. Without one or the other, you will spend a lot of time blundering around in the dark (which can be instructive, but is highly inefficient). So once you are fully comfortable with rigorous mathematical thinking, you should revisit your intuitions on the subject and use your new thinking skills to test and refine these intuitions rather than discard them. #mathematics #mathematicseducation

Does using a calculator make a mathematician less of a mathematician? Does it make your opinion of them lessen? Does it make you think they aren't a "real" mathematician? Or... do you think it helps them to focus on the creative side of math? Do you consider that maybe multiplying 658 with 762 is better done by a computer? Do you ever stop and wonder if maybe the rote is less important than the creative? Have you ever wondered what renowned mathematicians of old would have been able to accomplish if they didn't need to stop and calculate the square root of 134891034? My takeaways? 1. The fundamental rote "thinking" stuff that makes up any profession is critical AND can likely be done better, faster, and more reliably by a computer than a human. 2. The fundamental rote "thinking" stuff done by hand takes so much time and creative energy... both of which would be far better applied to other avenues. 3. Conformity will no longer bring value as a professional in the coming future. Do you disagree?
